title: The Stillwater Alibi
premise: When the town's most hated developer is found stabbed in the sealed, historic clock tower—a room only accessible by a single key held by the town's beloved, wheelchair-bound librarian—detective Elias Crowe must unravel a web of generational secrets. Every resident has a perfect, collective alibi for the time of the murder, witnessed at the annual 'Stillwater Solstice' bonfire. The solution lies not in who could have gotten in, but in why an entire town would lie to keep someone out.
protagonist: Elias Crowe, a disillusioned city detective who returned to his hometown after a personal tragedy, only to be thrust into its most confounding case.
conflict: Crowe must solve an impossible crime where the physical evidence points to one innocent woman, but the social evidence proves the whole town is conspiring to hide the truth, forcing him to choose between justice and the survival of the community he thought he knew.
setting: Present-day Stillwater, a picturesque but economically dying lakeside town where every family history is intertwined and preserved in a meticulously kept town archive.
tone: Atmospheric and claustrophobic, blending the puzzling intellect of a classic 'whodunit' with the creeping dread and buried guilt of a small-town Gothic thriller.
